titleStmt.title: M45. Anon. Holograph fragment, unsigned, dated Nov. 24, 1940. 11p.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M45. Anon. Holograph fragment, unsigned, dated Nov. 24, 1940. 11p.

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

p.l: Anon
"For many centuries after Britain became an island" the
historian says, "the untamed forest was king. " On the matted
branches of that forest innumerable birds sang; but
that song was heard only by a few few a few skin clad hunters in

a few the clearings an occasional clearing
wld Would the
desire to sing come to one of those savages because he

heard the birds sing?
Wld Would he rest his axe against a
tree for a moment & listen?
The tree was felled. Some sort of hut was made
from its branches; & then by degree, the clearing
gets larger & larger, the birds fewer & fewer, & the human
being sings instead. of [these?] The first songs are out of door songs,
[spring?] songs, summer songs, winter songs; as they
for there was no comfort indoors; no little light, & no
books.
The eye therefore was a much more important to the
first singers than to ourselves us. And what did he see?
And Some parts of England can still be seen as they saw them –
the fens, & the downs. It Now & then, by
choosing a view carefully, w with art to exclude a chimney or a
bungalow we can still see a flat reed whispering weed fen where nothing is vast heavy
[built?], water logged, or a high down bare; & then the
a track, like a green scar, & on a some [strang?] smooth
circle – the pack horses came along that road
the travelling [tithes?]; came along that road; &
as time went on, along which the travellers came [ready?] [illeg.]
as time went on the skins became were woolen cloaks:
were changed to wool cloth; he carried an a dagger the axe to a dagger

instead of a grey rock, to mark to mark by the [illeg.] play, the burial place there was a
cross.
Listen thus to some of the early songs:

quote.l: The lutel foul hath hire wyl
On her hyre lud to synge
Lif art gras ant blosme springes
Ich hav lovëd al this yer

p.l: That is the voice of Anon, singing out of doors,
singing because love & spring make him vocal;
but he, or she, has But who listens? What was

Somebody heard that particular song, or it

singer. And so was Anonymous

writing because it is not attached to a person.
Anon is only a voice. He has his representative today; to

The voice that broke that silence was
& the voice that sang was like a birds voice.
It was the voice of Anon singing out of doors.
Some one must have heard the song & noted it,
for it was remembered, & later written down.
The singer had his audience, but the audience was
so little interested in his name that he
never thought to give it. The audience
took part in the song. [illeg.]
they sang or clapped, or filling in the pause;
helping out the meaning

l.del: The author singer had no house, no name;

p.l: Anon is only a voice; without home, with
sex, without lodging He sings because the
spring has come, & winter is gone; because he loves
because he is hungry; or thirsty; or merry.
His songs are simple; but remembered because they
bear everybody shares the emotion & knows the story. the love of
Love; & fear, hunger & laughter are original
pure emotions the Anon therefore is the
common singer; the undifferentiated. He is
sometimes woman; sometimes man. We can
see him going never indoors, always out of
doors; seeing, the if the Anon is
has a very quick eye. He The eye is connected with the
body rather than the brain. He Anon has no
home. He lives a roaming out of door life,
out of doors, in Anon's day, was spring from

village to village, through along
strang strange paths, where
over the downs; hills; is seeing we can still sometimes

whispering, water logged, in a the a down with turf only,
covered with turf, & the scar on the down, along
wh. which Anon came, when he made his journeys.
It was Caxton who killed Anon. by
by giving him a name. It was Caxton made Anon

After that (1478) Anon becomes James & Thomas: he lives in a

And to seek follow his fortunes, we might turn to

But for him of course we have to wait until winter was past there is a
past. Time has to have drawn its blue veil over

p.l: have had time to think about the past, in the [seat?] of the

Skinner, Harrison, the parson of Radwinter, dug up the old
coins: & in the that were presumably set so

lover of the past. He already sees the present
against the past. He complains of the sees it
the past has become so settled that the already in
that the present looks [illeg.] crude, &
ungainly, false degenerate seen against its He The There is too much
comfort; too many much function, too many much silver,
pots; & too many chimneys, so that the living

the young
Shres Shakespeares & Marlowes are not the men their
fathers were. They have The smoke is drawn off
from the sitting room by chimneys, so that
instead of being bathed by the smoke that came
eddying round them they are tender, subject to
rheumatism. They dress fantastically compared with
their ancestors.
But England serves only the Harrisons past is not

p.l: That was the literature that occupied the same
place in Harrisons mind that the Elizabethans
occupy in our minds. When the The readers of his

libraries where the valuable books were
chained to the shelves. Or they were noble men &

But But As for It is against that He shuffles his pages

But he sees that The wandering singer, the [beginner?]

makes no show against those Greeks & Romans.
